title-group.article-title: Evaluation of Carotid Plaque Neovascularization Using Contrast Ultrasound

article-meta.aff: 1University of Birmingham Centre for Cardiovascular Sciences, City Hospital, Birmingham, United Kingdom
2Department of Vascular Surgery, City Hospital, Birmingham, United Kingdom

author-notes.corresp: Eduard Shantsila, University of Birmingham Centre for Cardiovascular Sciences, City Hospital, Birmingham, United Kingdom. Email: e.shantsila@bham.ac.uk

abstract.p: Contrast-enhanced ultrasound (CEUS) is increasingly used to improve visualization of carotid arteries. However, its reproducibility and utility for clinical research are not well established. The aim of the present study was to assess reproducibility of detection of carotid artery wall neovascularization using CEUS. Complete sequenced CEUS images from 10 individuals were analyzed for the presence of carotid arterial wall neovascularization. The images were acquired using Philips CompactXtreme CX50 ultrasound unit with an L12-3 probe and Bracco SonoVue contrast agent. The carotid wall neovascularization was graded by 2 independent observers with inter-/intraobserver agreement (κ) calculated. Interobserver κ values for intraplaque neovascularization (mean [95% confidence interval]) were 0.67 (0.40-0.94) for the left side. Interobserver κ values for intraplaque neovascularization were 0.65 (0.38-0.92). No study-related complications were observed. The CEUS method although semiquantitative shows moderate-to-strong intra- and interagreement for the results and can be used for clinical research purpose.

body.p: Atherosclerotic intraplaque neovascularization is associated with high-risk plaque destabilization. 1 Undernutrition and resulting ischemia of the growing atherosclerotic lesions triggers growth of new intrawall/intraplaque microvessels from adventitia, often being also associated with inflammatory processes. 2,3

Quantification of plaque neovascularization may improve identification of high-risk lesions, and limited clinical tools are currently available. Ultrasound contrast agents remain within the vascular space and, therefore, can be detected by their reflective resonation to highlight the presence of vascular disease. 4 More recently, carotid contrast imaging, an evolving technique, has been used to focus on the plaque and adventitial vasa vasorum. 4 However, reproducibility of the method is poorly established. 5
–10 The aim of the present work was to evaluate reproducibility of detection of carotid plaque vasculature using carotid contrast ultrasound.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: This validation study was performed on 10 complete sequenced ultrasound images selected randomly from a larger pool of 160 patients by an independent researcher (A.S.J.) and was individually analyzed for the presence of carotid arterial wall neovascularization. The personal details were removed from the scans to avoid possible bias during their assessment.

A Philips CompactXtreme CX50 (Bothel, Washington) portable ultrasound system with an L12-3 (3-12 MHz frequency) probe was used for imaging the carotid arteries. All images were captured digitally and transferred to a Philips multimodality image management system, Xcelera with QLAB 7.1 software, for analysis and assessment. All scans were performed by a single operator (A.S.). Each patient underwent ultrasound scanning with contrast in a single session. Images were acquired with the participant’s head rotated 45° away from the side of study. A magnified gray scale B-mode images of the carotid artery were obtained bilaterally at 3 levels, distal common carotid artery (CCA), carotid bifurcation, and the proximal internal carotid artery (ICA). 11 A single static image was captured for the CCA, and 2 images, each at different angles, were captured for the carotid bifurcation and the ICA. All still images were captured at end diastole. A 2- to 4-second real-time cine video of the CCA and carotid bifurcation was recorded, capturing at least 3 complete cardiac cycles. The Philips CX50 carotid contrast ultrasound presets were as follows: frequency: 26 Hz, dynamic range: 66, edge 3, Map G, Ave 2, and depth 3 cm.

SonoVue (Bracco Imaging S.p.A., Milan, Italy) contrast agent (sulfur hexafluoride microbubbles) was injected using a Vueject (BR-INF100) infusion pump (Bracco Imaging S.p.A.). SonoVue has a half-life of 6 minutes and is cleared by the respiratory system. 4 Documented overall reporting rate of serious adverse effects such as sensory motor paresis or chest pain with ST-segment elevation on electrocardiogram is less than 0.01%. 12 An infusion pump was used to achieve standardized results, by improving image quality and minimization of artifacts. 13,14 The contrast was infused via an antecubital vein (20 Gauge Venflon) with the rate of 1.3 mL/s with 6 mL of SonoVue typically used.

A linear array probe, with a mechanical index of 0.08 to 0.10, was used to achieve the best possible visualization of plaque morphology and vascularization, starting 30 seconds after beginning the infusion. During the contrast-enhanced ultrasound imaging, special attention was given to the previously identified lesions. All patients tolerated the examination well with no side effects. High-quality images were available for all the patients. After 30 minutes, the patients were deemed fit to go home.

Neovascularization was measured by 2 independent observers (reviewers A [E.S.] and B [A.S.J.]) to test interobserver variability and repeated by reviewer B (A.S.J.) to test intraobserver variability on 3 separate occasions (initial review, at week 2, and at 3 months). Plaque neovascularization was categorized as follows: grade 0—no contrast within the plaque; grade 1—bubbles confined to the plaque adventitial side; or grade 2—bubbles reaching the plaque core and/or contrast agent enhancement throughout the plaque (Figure 1).

caption.p: Contrast-enhanced carotid ultrasound. A, Carotid bifurcation with contrast agent. B, Grade 0 ICA lesion (no contrast within the plaque); C, grade 1 ICA lesion (bubbles confined to the plaque adventitial side); and D, grade 2 ICA lesion (bubbles reaching the plaque core and/or contrast agent enhancement throughout the plaque). CAR BIF indicates carotid bifurcation; ECA: external carotid artery; ICA, internal carotid artery.

sec.p: The agreement between the 2 reviewers or between different time points (kappa, κ) was calculated using SPSS version 19 (IBM, Armonk, NY). 15 Landis and Koch graded κ values as follows: κ <0—no conformity; κ = 0 to 0.20—slight agreement; κ = 0.2 to 0.40—fair agreement; κ = 0.41 to 0.60—moderate agreement; κ = 0.61 to 0.80—substantial agreement; and κ = 0.81 to 1—almost perfect agreement. 16

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Ten patients were studied (mean [standard deviation] age 66 [13] years, 50% male). Six patients had history of hypertension, 7 had stable coronary artery disease, 3 were current smokers, and 9 received statins. Two patients had no carotid stenosis, 4 had unilateral stenosis, and 2 participants had >50% stenosis. Interobserver κ values for intraplaque neovascularization (mean [95% confidence interval (CI)]) were 0.67 (0.40-0.94) for the left side. Interobserver κ values for intraplaque neovascularization (mean [95% CI]) were 0.65 (0.38-0.92) for measurements taken from both (ie, right and left) sides.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: There is a growing awareness that a number of molecular processes such as inflammation, lipid accumulation, angiogenesis, and thrombosis may occur at sites of plaque development and that these molecular processes are highly related to the physiological progression to rupture. 17 Although the precise method of remodeling of an asymptomatic plaque into a vulnerable plaque remains unclear, neovascularization has been implicated as an important contributor to plaque rupture. 18,19 Compared with stable patients, those with vulnerable coronary plaques had a 2-fold increase in their vasa vasorum density increasing further to 4-fold in ruptured plaques. 20 These changes in the arterial wall are not specific to any particular arterial bed but occur throughout the arterial vasculature, reflecting a systemic nature atherosclerosis. 21 –23

In the current study, it was possible to demonstrate, using a standardized technique with the use of SonoVue contrast agent, the presence of contrast agent within the atherosclerotic plaque. The study results confirm the potential of contrast-enhanced carotid ultrasonography for assessment of intraplaque neovascularization. 24 The inter- and intraobserver variability for detecting the presence of carotid plaque neovascularization can be acceptable for research purposes. Clinical utility of the approach needs to be assessed in prospective studies.

fn.label: Authors’ Note
fn.p: In this study Gregory Y. H. Lip and Eduard Shantsila are the joint senior authors.
